caseTitle: ANTHONY ABURIME v THE SECRETARY, ASSEMBLIES OF GOD MISSION
summary: The plaintiff brought a trespass action seeking damages, which the trial judge dismissed sua sponte on the grounds that the Supreme Court's jurisdiction was ousted under the proviso to section 12 of the Supreme Court Ordinance, as the matter allegedly involved title to land within the jurisdiction of a Native Court. The West African Court of Appeal held that the judge erred in dismissing the case without evidence or admission on two key points: (1) whether the suit raised an issue of title to land, and (2) whether a Native Court had jurisdiction over the land. The appellate court emphasized that jurisdiction cannot be ousted based on assumptions, and remitted the case for determination after proper evidentiary assessment.
citations: Supreme Court Ordinance, Cap. 211, s 12 proviso
rationaleHighlights: Trespass actions are based on possession and do not necessarily involve title to land.
Jurisdiction cannot be ousted without admission or evidence.
The trial judge erred by assuming Native Court jurisdiction without proof.
The proviso to section 12 only applies if both title and Native Court jurisdiction are established.
The court must be satisfied by evidence before declining jurisdiction.
Assumptions about jurisdiction are legally insufficient.
Remittal ordered for proper determination on evidence.
confidenceNotes: High confidence; all information is directly extracted from the judgment text. Case originates from the West African Court of Appeal, which had jurisdiction over Ghana (then Gold Coast) at the time.
